title: Google offers to buy Fitbit in bid to enter the wearable market - fitness tracker's stock soars
text:
Google owner Alphabet has made an offer to acquire U.S. wearable device maker, Fitbit.

According to sources interviewed by Reuters and CNBC, Google is interested in using the acquisition to make headway in the fitness tracking market where it would compete with other big tech companies like Apple.

The news on Monday sent Fitbit's stock soaring more than 30 percent and marks a first for Google in the fitness wearable arena.

Fitbit watches are used to track a wearer's biometrics like heart-rate and sleep quality and also come with a number of other tools like a clock and calendar.

Google is reportedly interested in buying the fitness wearable company, Fitbit - an acquisition that would help the company make headway in the wearable market (File photo)

While Google has joined other major technology companies such as Apple and Samsung in developing smart phones, it has yet to develop any wearable offerings, at least on the hardware end.

Google has long offered its Wear OS - an operating system designed for wearable devices - but has struggled to gain a foothold in a space increasingly dominated by Apple.

It's unclear if negotiations between Google and Fitbit will materialize a deal, said Reuters, whose sources asked not to be identified because the matter is confidential.

An exact price on Google's offer has not been reported.

For Fitbit, the offer may come with particularly apt timing as the company struggles to stave off the forward march of competitors like Apple.

According to CNBC, Apple has already overtaken nearly half of the smart watch market as of 2018 in terms of number of products shipped.

In July, Fitbit lowered expectations citing weaker sales of its new lightweight watch.

Google has never released wearable hardware despite briefly considering introducing a smart watch in 2016 (File photo)

Meanwhile Apple has continued to introduce new versions of its popular smart watch, including the recently unveiled Series 5 with a new display, features, and better processor.

As noted by The Verge, Google considered entering the smart watch field in 2016 but shied away from the plans citing concerns that the move could '...bring down the name of the Google hardware brand.'

Google has become increasingly focused on hardware throughout the past several years and has made headway in its efforts to sell smart home hardware like the Google Home and its Pixel line of smart phones.
description: According to sources multiple reports, Google is interested in using the acquisition to make headway in the fitness tracking market where it would compete with other tech giants like Apple.
